content: <@332923501079953409> Isn‚Äôt all this a good reason to use something like penalty_burn as I suggested above?

author: pintail_xyz
content: As legacy tx get more and more expensive, users will migrate to wallets and exchanges which have implemented native EIP 1559 transactions.

author: pintail_xyz
content: To recap the proposal is that legacy tx have a portion of their gas price burned before conversion to 1559 tx. The proportion that is burned is equal to `1559proportion` - the proportion of gas over (say) the last 1000 blocks which was spent on native 1559 transactions.

author: pintail_xyz
content: What this means is there is no penalty if no one is using native 1559 transactions

author: pintail_xyz
content: If 50% of transactions are using 1559 then legacy transactions are twice as expensive

author: pintail_xyz
content: If 90% of transactions use 1559 then legacy transactions are 10 times as expensive

author: pintail_xyz
content: etc

author: pintail_xyz
content: Once you have a run of 1000 blocks with no legacy transactions, then legacy transactions are no longer possible at all because the `penalty_burn` is 100%

author: pintail_xyz
content: Even without `penalty_burn`, legacy transactions will be significantly more expensive than native 1559 transactions, so I don't think the comparison with WIN32 is quite right. There is a transparent cost imposed on the user every time they do it the old way.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm surprised to be saying this, since my faith in humanity is notoriously low, but I actually do think the carrot only in this case is enough to get a non-trivial number of people to switch.

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree that it will not get *everyone* to switch, but unlike the dual-pool proposal this one will let us actually see what percentage of transactions have switch since there isn't arbitrage opportunity between the two types.

author: sky.cactus
content: So we can monitor the situation and eventually do a second hard fork that removes or taxes or whatever the legacy format.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think this new proposal results in a small amount of additional client complexity (less than the phased or transitional proposal), and it is strictly an improvement for any user that chooses to leverage it, and it will work indefinitely without being touched, and we retain the option of deprecating legacy transactions later if we so choose (which I am an advocate for).

author: sky.cactus
content: With 2718 (which I think we need for other reasons), the complexity of supporting multiple transaction types is a "sunk cost", and legacy transactions in a 1559 world are probably one of the easiest additional transaction types to support.

author: .funnyking
content:
Hello, from what I understood EIP1559 obtains two clear results and a more nuanced one, 1- it makes more predictable the price of gas at each successive block 2- it introduces a mechanism of deflation of the monetary mass (of the eth).
nuanced one: it introduces an elastic mechanism that expands and contrasts the gas limit x block and that encourages miners to include as many transactions as possible.

All 3 results are desirable for every ethereum stakeholder except the miners who today extract a lot from transaction fees and who would see their revenues greatly reduced and it is therefore possible that there may be a great deal of direct and indirect resistance/interference on their part. Something similar that I seem to have seen (I can be wrong about this) on the ProgPow issue.

From my point of view EIP-1559 should be introduced after having already substantially reduced the transaction fees that go to the miners with a much simpler and therefore less technically questionable and subject to lengthy discussions, i.e. burning a fixed % of transaction fees.

One can think of implementing this mechanism with successive protocol upgrades exactly as it was done in the past with the reduction of the reward per block, starting for example from 30% burned, then 50% and then 80% (approximately) provided by the current EIP-1559 specifications in order to reduce the impact of the rest of the changes for miners and indeed make them desirable.

author: .funnyking
content: I conclude by pointing out that today ethereum has become something similar to a role-playing game where a utility is extracted only if you participate in particular DeFi protocols, everything else is really too expensive, this means that those who do not have the ability or are not interested in these protocols get a much reduced utility from the use of ethereum, one way to mitigate the situation at least from this point of view is to offer to all stakeholders (who are supposed to have ether) an additional mechanism of deflation and eth value.
